text: do i even know what i'm doing right now
oh
hi everyone mystery drone here the
internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for a review of the new
sweet trip
album a tiny house in secret speeches
polar equals with it now being over a
decade
since the release of their last record
we now see the triumphant studio album
return
of sweet trip a san francisco cult
classic considered to be one of indie
music's true electronic innovators
seamlessly and subtly blending elements
of noise glitch
pop idm and more on the 2003 fan
favorite velocity design comfort
and while this record does loom large
and sweet trips
scant discography it's also important to
remember the 2009 follow-up you will
never know why
which was a lot more guitar driven by
comparison
less glitchy overall too which is fine
because i think the tunes
showed a bit brighter on this one and
while this might be where the duo left
off there's really no telling after all
of these years
where their sound may end up next but
honestly after listening to this
i'm pretty happy to say roberto and
valerie are not stuck in the past
they stay true to their electronic and
indie roots on this one
while leaning into the dream pop and
shoegaze elements of their sound
harder than they have before which makes
a tiny house a record you can really get
lost in with its relaxed lead vocals
surreal layers of guitars
keys and electronics that bleed into
each other
creating this soothing wall of sound the
duo sometimes extends these tracks out
into five
six seven minute lengths really trying
to flush
every idea out of these pieces they can
and allowing these songs to really wash
over the listener in a sublime way
it's a vibe but also engaging it is shy
and soft to the touch but pops on key
tracks too
the opening track for example is some of
the best shoe gaze i've heard in a bit
the pulsating beats shimmering
electronics and fuzzy walls of guitar
make this a rowdy but serene kickoff to
the record
the howling layers of lead melodies
around the midpoint of the track too
feel like i'm
running across a beach that's melting
under my feet
then the following surviving a smile
with its
gently pulsating rhythms curious chords
and melancholy vocal harmonies delivered
in a hushed fashion
it sounds like what you would get if
eliot smith were forced to make an
electro pop tune
and i couldn't be happier with the
results the weight of comfort the rain
is comfort
sounds like dream pop's long-awaited
answer to ballroom music but it's all
soaked in these delays that
cause almost each piece of
instrumentation here to ripple out into
infinity
meanwhile the track chapters is really
the closest thing we have to a visceral
banger here
the track has a relaxed tune set to
punchy electro pop beats
some cute analog synth patches and
little touches of noise peppered
throughout the track to add some extra
texture eve foolery mill
5 is like the record slow dance number
listening to it feels like being crowned
king and queen at the dream pop prom
so all of these tracks collectively
contribute to a very strong first half
for this lp
but as i dug into this record deeper
i found the second half isn't quite as
beefed up as the first
whether it's running thin on sonic ideas
or well-structured songs
it seems like the potential for a tiny
house drifts
further and further away as we push past
the halfway point
for one the quirky and noisy glitches
strewn about snow purple treasures
kind of harshes the vibe which isn't
usually the case as sweet trip
incorporates elements of noise
into their tracks but for some strange
reason it is here
either way it just seems like they're
getting in the way of their own euphoria
on this one
randfilt is a somewhat cheeky unexpected
instrumental piece that goes in an idm
direction
which is obviously a genre sweet trip
has dabbled in before
but it seems especially out of place on
this very hazy track list
not to mention some of the beats on this
cut run a little stiff meanwhile u
is a super promising song to start but
then it gets more and more disjointed as
it continues
with each portion of the track breaking
off into another direction
or variant that feels like it's heading
toward a destination
that's not really there then there's
walkers beware we drive into the sun
which has a painfully bland first half
that is sadly not made
up for in the predictably loud shoegaze
second half
zafire is a kind of goofy interlude
again
another one that doesn't really add too
much to the record at this point
then the ending of this lp is kind of
the moment of truth with two six minute
songs back to back
the first of which is polar equals which
i found to be okay while it was
on but structurally it's one of the most
tedious tracks here
the whole first portion is really slow
going only for it to eventually
transition into a build that
once again kind of hits a wall of sound
with an
instrumental palette that isn't too much
unlike any other on this record at
various points
then we get a somewhat anticlimactic
finish which is unfortunate because
it seems apparent the duo is trying to
make this ending as climactic as
possible with all of its glistening
synth layers and
speedy tom heavy drum beats but
ultimately it just kind of sounds like a
piece of music that you would hear
at the end of an 80s movie where they're
like updating you
on everything that like all the
characters are doing
mixed with a touch of angelus and just
about as much reverb as the duo could
pack
into this mix which is not a bad set of
influences to be working from in concept
but once this track hits its stride
it really doesn't build or go anywhere
from there still though ultimately i
found this record to be
pretty enjoyable not a bad project from
sweet trip considering all the years
it's been
and the slight change in sound that this
record presents yeah
in my view the second half was severely
lacking something the first half had
but i still think the duo came through
in a big way on this one and if they can
make a record this good so many years
past the point of their last studio
record
they can make an even better one in the
near future i'm feeling a strong six to
a light seven
on this one tran position have you given
this album a listen did you love it did
you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
